person_520.name: Jean-AndréDeluc
person_520.description: Swiss-born geologist, natural philosopher and meteorologist who spent much of his time working in England. FRSL.

person_267.name: Abraham GottlobWerner
person_267.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

person_125.name: JamesHutton
person_125.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.

person_085.name: Plato
person_085.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

place_878.name: United States
place_878.description: The U.S. is a country of 50 states covering a vast swath of North America, with Alaska in the northwest and Hawaii extending the nation’s presence into the Pacific Ocean.

place_685.name: New Holland
place_685.description: New Holland was the name first given to Australia by the Dutch seafarer, Abel Tasman.

place_571.name: Mull
place_571.description: The Isle of Mull is the second-largest island of the Inner Hebrides (after Skye) and lies off the west coast of Scotland.

place_1055.name: Logan Rock
place_1055.description: a ninety-ton granite boulder perched on the edge of the cliffs overlooking the English Channel, on a headland one mile south of Treen.

place_1317.name: Aswan
place_1317.description: a city in Southern Egypt, previously known as the ancient city of Swenett, later known as Syene, which in antiquity was the frontier town of Ancient Egypt facing the south.

place_995.name: Ben Nevis
place_995.description: the highest mountain in Scotland, the United Kingdom and the British Isles.

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

place_247.name: Alps
place_247.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

place_013.name: St Michael's Mount
place_013.description: St Michael's Mount is a tidal island in Mount's Bay, Cornwall, with a distinct conical shape.

place_998.name: Pyrenees
place_998.description: The Pyrenees mountain range separates the Iberian Peninsula from the rest of Europe, stretching more than 430km between Spain and France and rising higher than 3,400m in elevation.

place_1320.name: Swiss Alps
place_1320.description: The Alpine region of Switzerland, conventionally referred to as the Swiss Alps, extend over both the Western Alps and the Eastern Alps, encompassing an area sometimes called Central Alps.

place_177.name: Andes
place_177.description: Mountain range in western South America.
